title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.17.3 | 14-02-2023
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.summary: This segment introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam and explains how the cow represents mother earth and the exploitation of resources in Kali Yuga.
segments.transcript: In this session, we are discussing from the third verse of the 17th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam: Gaamcha Dharma Dughaam Deenam Prasham Shudra Padahatam Vivatsam Ashruvadanam Ksham Maam Yavasam Ichchateem. The meaning of this verse is, although the cow is beneficial because one can draw religious principles from her, she was now rendered poor and calfless. Her legs were being beaten by a shudra. There were tears in her eyes, and she was distressed and weak. She was hankering after some grass in the field. Earlier, the condition of the bull was described. Now the condition of the cow is being described. Cow is representing mother earth, and how people in Kali Yugaam exploit the resources of material.

segments.key_quote: Nobody can be happy if they do not perform sacrifice.
segments.summary: This segment explains the importance of sacrifice, the use of ghee in sacrifices, and the connection between sacrifice, happiness, and rainfall, emphasizing the need for sacrifice for Vishnu.
segments.transcript: was save. And that ghee is used in sacrifices, fire sacrifices, particularly. And the performing sacrifices, the householder can be happy. Parjanya means rains. There will be no proper rainfall if one does not perform sacrifice for Vishnu.

segments.key_quote: But in Kali Yuga, the calves are separated from the cows as early as possible.
segments.summary: This segment describes the natural bond between cow and calf and how it is disrupted in Kali Yuga due to exploitation, particularly the mistreatment of male calves.
segments.transcript: Now, further Srila Prabhupada says, the cow's calf, the young one of the cow, not only is beautiful to look at but also gives satisfaction to the cow, and the cow delivers as much milk as possible when the calf is properly protected and the cow is able to have the calf with her. But in Kali Yuga, the calves are separated from the cows as early as possible for purposes which cannot be mentioned in these pages of the Srimad Bhagavatam. They don't want to allow especially the male calves to remain and to survive because a cow may give birth to a male calf or a female calf. But they want only the female calf because they can milk it. Whereas the male calf, they don't know how to utilize the bull, the male calf. When it grows, it can actually produce grains. It can do so many things, so many things. But because they do not know how to engage the bulls, they provide milk to the cow. They give them milk but they don't want to do that. They allow the cow to get the milk of the cow and give them protection and utilize them in a proper way.

segments.key_quote: These greatly sinful acts are responsible for all the troubles in the present society.
segments.summary: This segment details the sinful acts of separating calves from cows, artificially milking cows, and sending them to slaughterhouses, linking these actions to societal problems.
segments.transcript: Therefore, they don't allow these calves to survive, to remain, especially male calves. The cow stands with tears in her eyes and the shuttle milkman draws milk from the cow artificially. The cow will give milk only after the calf has taken its share. The cow will be satisfied to give plenty of milk. But now the calf is not allowed to drink the cow's milk at all, and the calf is separated from the cow very, very early. And how do they make the cow give milk? They force the cow to give milk. They will use a pump, artificial pump to suck out the milk from the cow. The cow is unwilling to give when the calf is not there. And when there is no milk, the cow is sent to be slaughtered. The cow will give milk for some number of years. After it becomes old, it stops giving milk and immediately send it to the slaughterhouse for being slaughtered. The cow is then butchered for cow flesh.

segments.key_quote: The laws of nature will work regardless of whether people have belief or people are educated or uneducated.
segments.summary: This segment discusses the consequences of sinful acts and violating the laws of nature and God, even in the pursuit of economic development, leading to suffering.
segments.transcript: These greatly sinful acts are responsible for all the troubles in the present society. Very, very sinful. To kill the cow, to kill the male calf, doesn't even have a chance of surviving, living its normal lifespan. And people do not understand that this is very, very sinful. It means the laws of nature will work regardless of whether people have belief or people are educated or uneducated. And people have to suffer in so many ways. People do not know what they are doing in the name of economic development. They are just concerned with somehow making money, but they do not realize that while it is not entirely wrong to strive for economic development or earning money, but the way it is done is if it is not in accordance with the laws of nature, the laws of God, then people have to suffer so much.

segments.key_quote: If you want to be happy as a human being, you should ensure that cows and bulls are protected and they are happy in all respects.
segments.summary: This segment concludes by emphasizing the importance of cow and bull protection for peace, prosperity, and happiness in society, advocating for a Brahmanical culture where cows and Brahmanas are protected.
segments.transcript: The consequences of violating God's laws. The influence of Kali will keep the people in this age in the darkness of ignorance. Despite all endeavors for peace and prosperity, they must try to see the cows and the bulls happy in all respects. If you want to be happy as a human being, you should ensure that cows and bulls are protected and they are happy in all respects. Otherwise, if the cows and bulls are not happy, they are not given proper protection, human beings have to suffer and there will be no peace and prosperity in human society where cows and bulls are particularly not properly protected. Foolish people do not know how one can earn happiness by making the cows and bulls happy, but it is a fact by laws of nature. The laws of nature people do not know. They are doing some research to find out. Some research to find out how things are working in nature, but they do not have the authoritative knowledge from the perfect source, from God to the Vedas. Let us take it from the authority of Srimad Bhagavatam and adopt the principles for the total happiness of human society. So Bhagavatam teaches us that we should have this Brahmanical culture, whereby Brahmanas are protected, Brahmanas direct the society and the cows are protected and the cows are giving us wonderful milk and they are happy in every respect, so that there is peace and prosperity in human society.
